I've been thinking for this, but the idea is to make a physics manager server that the physics/computationally intensive program (KSP or powder toy with 1x1 pressure grid) connect into it, and several computation units connects to the server. The computational unit can be located in the playing computer itself (multithreading without the program needing to be thread safe) or it could be located on other computer. So, in short, if your game lags, just throw more computers into it. This have an advantage that a normal supercomputer cluster could run the computation units

If KSP have a lot of this brute force physics power, maybe all the things/vessels doesn't need to be on rails

The problem is: Is it possible? I'm not a programmer myself

I think the problem is that PhysX is built into Unity3D and there is no way around that. I don't think you can just plug in another physics implementation. If that was possible, Squad probably would already have done that for KSP.

So why can`t you have a program running Unity that is handling physics with PhysX under Unity 3D that is controlled by a message passing interface? Then you have a `mod` program handled by a message passing interface and so forth with a main controller program. Split the host PC into many 4Gb sections each with their own domain of control that recieve inputs and pass outputs.

Unless Unity cannot pass information to another program in real time I don`t see the problem as far as it being possible.

It would be a pig to program though with all the different setups people have and would require a rewrite from the ground up.
